The novelist Richard Russo heard a story once.
True or not, it was a tale of a cop who discovered something strange in his wife's belongings, a garage door opener.
And so he actually went around town.

People saw him going up one street and down the other, pointing this garage door remote at various garages, having concluded that if he could find the house where the garage door went up, he would've found his wife's lover.
Richard Russo built a novel on this tale.
Everybody's Fool"" centers on a middle-aged man with questions about his late wife.
Indeed, about his whole life.
It's a sequel to ""Nobody's Fool,"" which became a movie in the '90s starring Paul Newman and Philip Seymour Hoffman.
They're blue-collar guys in a blue-collar town, an old city in upstate New York that used to have mills and factories, used to be something.
This is Richard Russo's world, the kind of place he grew up.
The main character in the novel reflects he was a C student, which gives him a certain local prominence since the A students long ago left town.
Russo did get out of town but still relates to the people he left behind.

Rather like their author I suppose, they have reached a point in life where they are looking ahead at an uncertain future but more importantly, looking backwards and trying to - I don't know - figure out what the shape is in the carpet, the figure in the carpet, what has of all of this added up to.
The figure in the carpet, he's referring there to an old short story whose meaning has always been mysterious.
Richard Russo's main character attends a funeral in a local cemetery where he is coming to know more and more of the people buried there.
The soil beneath where so many people lay interred has begun to erode.
And so when you go to visit grandma and you stand before her headstone, you have no guarantee anymore that grandma's still there.
She may have moved down the slope a ways.
So the dead in this book are on the move, which is another way of suggesting, of course, that they are not fixed in there anymore that they're fixed in our memories.
They have more to say to us when they're gone if we're the sort to listen.
Do you have the whole geography of this fictional town in your head?
I kind of do, yeah.
I know with all of my books.
If Miles Roby walks out of the diner in Empire Falls and goes to visit Mrs. Whiting, I know whether he has to turn right or left.
And I can feel Sully's knee throb when he walks from, you know, Hatties (ph) in the morning down to the OTB.
I have a pretty good sense of the geography of my places.

When you talked with us about eight years ago, you said that you don't actually write about place, even though there is such a powerful sense of place in your books, that you're really writing about class.
And I'm thinking about that now because class is so much more on people's minds now than I think it maybe was a number of years ago.
What has made you think about class so intensely all these years?

I suspect it's because my own life has changed so dramatically in ways that I never would have predicted, coming from a small mill town in upstate New York, from parents and grandparents who didn't think of themselves as poor but didn't have any money.
I find myself now at 66, having lived the American dream to a point at which I think would have completely mystified my maternal grandfather.

Were he to be standing here now on the other side of the glass of this studio that I'm talking to you in and see where I am, the life that I'm living, which is, of course, the life that he would've dreamed for me had he been that ambitious a dreamer, is pretty astonishing.
Think you are saying - I feel like you're saying something important about your grandfather that probably applies to a lot of us.
You're saying that he could not have imagined going much beyond the station in life that he had been born into or could not have imagined you going much beyond that station in life.
Well, you know, he and my mother...
...Not that he was against it, just he couldn't picture it.
Well, no, no, no - no, no - no, it's - see, that's right.
Imagination - you don't spring from the air into the air.
You spring from the ground into the air.
And that ground that I sprang from is in Gloversville, N.Y.

And it would've seemed like arrogance, I think, to my grandfather to assume that he was ever going to be living a hugely different life from the life that he lived from the time that he was a boy and then a young man.
So I want you to read something if you wouldn't mind.
Sure.
And it's about one of your main characters, Sully, who is at a point in his life where after this really vigorous, blue-collar existence, he's come into some money various ways.
And he's comfortable.
He doesn't have to work anymore.
OK.
(Reading) What all this amounted to, in Sully's estimation, was a cosmic joke.
As a poor man, he'd always suspected that life's deck was stacked in favor of those with means.
Was it possible, without intending to, he'd actually become one of them?
Was he now and forever more insulated against adversity?
How exactly should he feel about that?
Other people rose to the challenge and learned how to live with good fortune.
Why not him?
(Laughter) I love that.
(Laughter).
And listening to you, I wonder if that is sometimes you being uncomfortable with your own good fortune.
No, it's always me, not sometimes.
(LAUGHTER)
Yeah, yeah, there was absolutely no imagination involved at all in writing that paragraph.
That's just - I wake up in the morning and something like that thought every time, you know, how did this happen?
Special counsel Robert Mueller mentioned WikiLeaks as Organization 1 in charges earlier this year against a dozen Russian military intelligence officers.
They were charged with conspiring to defraud the United States.
The idea is that basically WikiLeaks was acting as a cutout for emails swiped from the Democratic National Committee and other Democrats in 2016.
But it's not clear what - if any - of all of that activity forms the basis of these charges against Julian Assange.
I reached out to his American lawyer Barry Pollack today.
Barry Pollack said the last thing this Justice Department should be doing is pursuing criminal charges against someone for publishing truthful information.
He says this is a dangerous path.
And none of this has anything to do with the charges against him in Sweden related to sexual misconduct, which is its own story.
Another story, yeah.
Assange has been living in the Ecuadorian embassy in London for years now.
And I understand his life there has changed recently.
Tell us about that.
It really has.
Ecuador has a new president who's far less happy with Julian Assange and who's been trying to warm up relations with American officials, like Vice President Mike Pence and President Trump.
Recently, the Ecuadorians have laid down the law with Assange, Ari.
They say he needs to keep his room in this embassy clean and also pick up after his cat.
And their patience seems to be wearing very thin with respect to Julian Assange, who's been there since 2012 - six years now.
So where does this go from here?
